title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. Lifelong railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits; those with non-railroad employment receive benefits from either RRB or Social Security, depending on their railroad service length. Railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker needs at least 10 years of covered railroad work or five years after 1995. Family members of insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities equal to or greater than Social Security benefits they would have received. If a worker doesn't qualify for an RRB annuity, their railroad work counts toward Social Security. Railroad workers receive RRB annuities equal to or greater than Social Security benefits. RRB annuities have two components: tier I, equivalent to Social Security benefits, and tier II. Tier I amounts increase annually with a cost-of-living adjustment. Railroad workers receive RRB annuities based on age, service, and covered employment. Tier I amounts, similar to Social Security benefits, increase annually with a cost-of-living adjustment. Tier II retirement amounts, based solely on covered railroad service, are paid in addition to tier I amounts and increase annually by 32.5% of the Social Security COLA. Surviving spouses may be eligible for widow or widower benefits. RRB survivor annuities for railroad workers' spouses are generally higher than Social Security benefits, as they include tier II amounts. Surviving spouses may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Workers may be entitled to tier II amounts in addition to tier I amounts, equivalent to Social Security benefits. A surviving spouse may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Widows and widowers as early as age 60 (or 50 if disabled) may receive a reduced annuity. A widow(er) caring for a deceased worker's child under 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100% of the worker's tier II amount. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 (P.L. 107-90) was based on joint recommendations negotiated by railroad labor. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 (P.L. 107-90) increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widows(er)s. Other provisions in the law include allowing investment in non-governmental assets and removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience retiring at age 60 or 61. The 2001 Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act made several changes, including allowing investment in non-governmental assets, removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience retiring at age 60 or 61, reducing the years required to be fully vested for tier II annuities, repealing a maximum limitation on annuities, and phasing in changes to the tier II tax structure. The changes to widow(er)'s annuities apply to recipients starting in February 2002 or later, and some recipients before that date may also benefit from the new rules. The 2001 law changed widow(er)'s annuities for those starting in February 2002 or later. Some recipients before that date may also benefit if they would have received a higher benefit under the new rules. The law added a guaranty amount increasing initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s by adding a new guaranty amount. This supplemental guaranty amount is set at 50% of the employee's tier II amount. The total initial minimum amount under the current law is 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts the employee would have received at the time the widow(er) begins to receive an annuity, minus any applicable reductions. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s by adding a new guaranty amount, set at 50% of the employee's tier II amount. The widow(er)'s regular annuity components change over time, with tier I and regular tier II amounts increasing annually based on Social Security COLA. Each year's COLA amount is offset by a reduction to the guaranty amount. The widow(er)'s annuity amounts increase annually based on Social Security COLA, with tier I amounts increasing by the same percentage and regular tier II amounts by 32.5% of the COLA. The guaranty amount is reduced by the same dollar amount as the COLA increase, resulting in no change to the total monthly annuity for several years. Eventually, when the guaranty amount reaches zero, the widow(er) will see an increase in their total monthly annuity for the first time. The widow(er)'s annuity amounts increase annually based on Social Security COLA, with tier I amounts increasing by the same percentage and regular tier II amounts by 32.5% of the COLA. The guaranty amount is reduced to zero, leading to an increase in the total monthly annuity for the widow(er) for the first time. All widow(er)s eligible for the initial minimum amount under the 2001 law receive annuities greater than or equal to those under prior law. In 2001, the average aged widow(er) annuity awarded was $1,138 per month in real 2005 dollars. Under the 2001 law, widow(er)s receive annuities greater than prior law. In 2005, average widow(er) annuity was $1,416 per month. Widow's initial annuity is calculated based on current law. Under current law, a widow at full retirement age whose husband died in 2006 would receive an initial minimum amount of $1,300 per month. This includes $1,000 from tier I and $300 from tier II. The tier II annuity also includes a regular amount of $150 and a guaranty amount of $150, totaling 50% of what her husband would have received in 2006. Under current law, a widow's total annuity amount is $150 more than what she would have received under prior law, consisting of $1,300 per month with $1,000 from tier I and $300 from tier II. The widow's total annuity will not increase due to COLAs until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed her initial minimum amount, remaining at $1,300 between 2006 and 2012. The components of her annuity would change each year. The widow's total annuity of $1,300 per month will not increase between 2006 and 2012. However, the components of her annuity, such as tier I and regular tier II amounts, would change each year. For example, her tier I amount would increase from $1,000 in 2006 to $1,023 in 2007, while her regular tier II amount would increase from $150 to $151 during the same period. This results in a $24 increase in the regular annuity, offset by a decrease in the guaranty amount. In 2007, the widow's total tier II annuity under current law would be $277, with a $24 increase in the regular annuity offset by a decrease in the guaranty amount. Despite no COLA, her annuity is higher than under prior law. Starting in 2012, her total monthly annuity will gradually increase due to COLAs as her guaranty amount decreases to zero. In 2012, the widow's total monthly annuity would increase due to COLAs, with her guaranty amount gradually decreasing to zero. Her total monthly annuity under current law would be $1,323 in 2012, higher than the $1,300 in 2011. This amount would remain the same each year thereafter. Under current law, the widow's total monthly annuity would be $1,323 in 2012, higher than her 2011 amount of $1,300. The amount remains the same each year thereafter. The widow also receives a guaranty amount under current law. Under prior law, the widow's monthly annuity in 2006 would have been $1,150, consisting of tier I and tier II amounts. However, under current law, the widow also receives a guaranty amount, bringing her total annuity in 2006 to $1,300. The guaranty amount decreases each year after 2006 as tier I and tier II amounts increase due to an annual offset.
